div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: BATTLE OF HEI-KOU-TAI. FURTHER FIGHTING. GEN. GRIPENBERG RECALLED.
div.p: Tokio, February 3. The battle of Hei-kou-tai was more extensive and desperate was originally indicated. The result of the battle hung in the balance. After four days of fighting, the Japanese were in a critical position and outnumbered. Oyama finally ordered night attacks by all the columns on the 28th ult, which the Russians were unable to withstand. The latter began to retreat, whereupon the Japanese charged and occupied Hei-kou-tai on the morning of the 29th. ult (Reuter.)

Tokio, February 3. Marshal Oyana reports that the Japanese casualties from the 33th to the 29th January last were 7,000. The Russians had at least 10,000. The prisoners state that four infantry regiments were nearly annihilated (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, February 3. General Kuropatkin reports that the Japanese on the 1st inst, after a hot bombardment, attacked Djantankenam, on the left bank of the Hun-Hor and drove out the Russians. The litter, having been reinforced, recaptured the village. It is stated here that General Gripenberg, who comm the troops at Hei-kou-tai, has relinquished his command on the ground of ill health. General Oyloff succeeds him. (R.)
St. Petersburg, February 5. General Gripenberg has been recalled for reasons of health. (Havas).

div.head: RUSSIAN DISTURBANCES. THE WARSAW CASUALTIIES TROUBLES AT LODZ.
div.p: Warsaw, February 3. There is now no doubt that the casualties at Warsaw far exceeded those of the Capital. The dead were buried at night guarded by troops. The looting was due to Hooligans, who wore incited by the police in order to discredit the movement. A hand of workmen yesterday entered the Hooligan quarter and killed all whom they found in possession of plunder. (Reuter).
London, February 3. A strike has broken out in the coal district of Dombrova and Sosnowic, on which Warsaw and Lodz depend for their entire coal supply. (Reuter).
Lodz, February 3. Serious disturbances have taken place hen today, where the strikers number 250,000. The mob fought the troops with revolvers. There were many killed and wounded. (R.)
Warsaw, February 3. It is estimated that in the recent trouble-600 people were killed or wounded. (R).

div.head: THE TSAR’S UKASE.
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 3 With reference to one section of the Tsar's Ukase relating to the reforms, the Committee of Ministers decided to recommend a series of measures for limiting individual initiative of Ministers with the Tsar, and specially as regards the alteration and suspension of laws, for increasing the control and the initiative of the Senate in this latter connection, for facilitating the prosecution of officials by private persons fur illegalities, for the establishing of local courts in connection with the Senate, and for the provision of educated jurymen where the question of the loss of civil rights is involved. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. MOVEMENTS OP SQUADRONS.
div.p: Djibouti, February 3. Admiral Botrovosky's squadron has left for Madagascar, is German colliers are following the squadron. (Reuter.)
London, February 3. Lloyd's learns from Mauritius that the Baltic Fleet was still at Nossi Be on the 28th January. (Reuter.)
Manila, February 3. The American Fleet has left for the south of the archipelago in order to maintain neutrality there. (R.)

div.head: The Mahmal
div.p: arrived at Jeddah yesterday. Tin Brindisi Mail closes at the G. P. 0. Alexandria, at 3 p m. tomorrow. The Fitzer Quatuor will give two more rentals at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on the 17th and 24th inst.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 1st inst 6 vessels, all British, passed through the Canal, the dues from which amounted to fr. 244,396.36.

div.head: National Bank or Egtpt
div.p: The new agencies of this bank at Benha, Damanhour, Shebin el-Kom, Beni Souef, Keneh, Sohag, aud Assouan have commenced working this week.

div.head: The Pirates of Penzance."
div.p: The performance of "The Pirates of Penzance," we are informed, is to take place in Cairo ou the 22nd iust, aud not on the 17th, as the Duke of Connaught not arrive in Cairo until the 17th inst. An Important Postal Innovation will come into force on April 1, when a postal order service will be established between Egypt and Great Britain and her colonies. No other country has such a system in vogue in connection with the Egyptian Postal Administration.

div.head: The Freres' Case
div.p: The “Chambre Correctionuele” of the Appeal Court at Aix will hear the appeal of M. Leon Yayon against the judgment given by the French Consular Coart at Cairo against him for libelling the Christian Brothers, on the 9th inst.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: The quantity of coal imported from 1st January to 2nd inst was 32,338 tons, as against 60,417 for the same period last year. Newcastle sent 5,833 tons, the Welsh districts 19,804, Scotch 4,668, Yorkshire 1,786, other districts 247.

div.head: Egyptian Institute
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Egyptian Institute on Monday afternoon next at 3 o’clock. Yacoub Pasha Artin will lecture on "8ome Artistic Curios of the Fourteenth Century," and Dr. Apostolidis will discuss "Hellenism in Egypt before the Macedonian Age.” There will be some elections of new members after the meeting.

div.head: Mysterious Disappearance
div.p: We regret to learn that Raoul Sakakiui, second son of Sakakiui Boy, of Alexandria, has been missing since Thursday last. The boy is 15 years of age and is a bright, intelligent lad, enjoying the best of health. He left home on Thursday for a walk, and since then all the efforts of the Alexandria police and detectives have been utterly unable to trace his movements or discover his whereabouts. Lately, there have been some other cases of the sudden disappearance of young boys from Alexandria.

div.head: Armenian Benevolent Society
div.p: The Zizinia Theatre was crowded last night on the occassion of the special performance of "Le Petit Lord” tor the benefit of the Armenian Benevolent Society of Alexandria. All the boxes were decorated with flowers and the audience was representative of the cream of Alexandrian society. The play was well acted. Miss Loyer as Cedric Errol was charming and acted the part of little Poutleroy to perfection. M. Foamier as the Duke of Dorincourt was also good End the minor porta were well filled. After the play various artists recited. M. Plan, whose volume of poems is criticised in another part of to-day’s issue, gave bis poem of “La Femme da Marin” and the taste and emotion of his recital were greatly relished by the audience. Miss Daussmond and Miss Loyer gave some pretty monologues and the evening ended with Calmette’s farce “En Voitnre.”

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd’ hui a midi et damie) La reprise des cotons, en attirent lee specula teurs a la corbeille dee manchandises, a en traine du mime coop la depreciation et le de laissement de la oorbeille des valours. Aussi avont-nous peu d’affaires a enregistrer quel qaes Oasis et denx ou trois changes end autres valours, et o'est tout. Malgre cela, le marche se maintient relative ment ferine.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA SCANDAL. END OP HEARING.
div.p: The further hearing of Mr. Ninci's petition fora judicial separation from his wife, on the ground of her adultery with Judge Constantine Dimiaras, late President of the Hellenic Consular Tribunal at Alexandria, was continued yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock before the Italian Consular Court, under the presidency of Judge Palqui, assisted by Mr. Amabile Cumbo and Mr. Arrera. Maltre Colucci, counsel for the petitioner, disputed the authenticity of one of the letters read to the Court by Maltre Guidotti. This letter was supposed to have been written by the wife's father, complaining of her husband maltreatment. The Judge, on examining the writing, pronounced it to be a forgery. Counsel for the wife then explained I that the document in question not an original manuscript, but simply a translation I from the Greek to Italian. He promised to bring the original letter into Court.

Maltre Coluoci then began to controvert the arguments of the council for the defence, and showed that the first line of defence was based on five points, in order to prove I that the fault lay with the husband via, (R).

That Mr. Ninci neglected his wife when ill. (II). That he was a man of depraved tastes. [III). That he had a very violent temper. (IV). That be insulted his wife prior to the hear 1 ng of the case by inserting articles in the Press. (R).

The Helouan incident Maltre Dolucei refuted each of these charges. He showed that Mr. Ninoi wave loving and dutiful, and that many witnesses could be brought into Court to prove that during his wife's illness his conduct had been most sympathetic. The truth was that he idolized his wife, that the responsible position which he now 1 bolds as the commercial manager here of so important a company as that of the Rxffinerie d’Egypto, showed. That laboured most seriously in order to enrich his wife. When he had attained that i position, his wife had ruined his lile by her t flagrant infidelity. As to the disgraceful allegations in regard to the perverted instincts of his client, Maltre Coluoci said that such charges were always tramped up in these matrimonial cases in order to blacken the husband’s character. She has complained during the eight years of her married life, and she now, through her counsel, declared that her husband began to display his deprived character three days after the marriage ceremony. Maitre Coluoci then read some very significant letters from the lady to her husband. He went on to speak of her hypocritical and homeless conduct towards her husband, and that if Mr. Ninci was guilty of violent behaviour, it was only natural considering that , it had been tried so much, and as to the Helouan incident, be had only smacked his wife. In regard to the second line of defence, tamely, that the reconciliation of husband and his wife annulled the claim of the husband to a official separation, Maitre Colucci declared that the reconciliation was only of a tacit and thus did not invalidate the subsequent claim for a separation. He then declared that the wife's conduct was very like the rise of the heroine of Paul Bourget's "Cruelle Bnigme,” for, although she loved her husband, yet she was unable to resist deceiving him. Mr. Ninci loved his wife to distraction, and his passionate devotion to her fully explained the alleged violence of his conduct and his weakness in submitting to a momentary reconciliation at Helouan. Counsel then cited a number of legal authorities, all showing that to divest a husband of his right to a judicial separation, the reconciliation between him and his erring wife should be tantamount to a complete resumption of marital relations. But in the case in question this was not so but was merely a trick of his wife’s lover, Judge Constantine Dimaras, who, knowing the intricacies of the Italian aa well as of the Hollenio Code, had suggested to his mistress that she should be temporarily reconciled with her husband, and then provoke an incident, such as occurred at Helouan, in order that she herself should be the first to ask for a judicial separation. The diabolical ingenuity of the judge was successful. He pretended that he had a difference with his mistress and left Egypt, but when the Helouan incident had taken place he at once returned to Alexandria. I Mr. Ninci was not quite certain of his wife's infidelity prior to the reconciliation; he merely I had very strong suspicions, suggested by the discovery that his wife always wore a scapular and a portrait of the judge concealed in her bosom, as well as by the impassioned Greek poems ho had found in the house addressed to his wife by the judge. Counsel then proved that Mr. Ninci was not certain of his wife's misconduct at that time, because when Mr. Ninoi desired to have a duel with the judge, the seconds came to an arrangement As the seconds were very respectable gentlemen, it was impossible for them to oome to arrange matters if there had been any certainty as to the adultery. Until the last moment had continued her relations with the judge in a house in Sesostris-street, and when the judge left for the Pinens last week, she had a terrible attack of hysteria, which disturbed all the inhabitant# of the opponent. This fully showed the "diabolical persistence” of her passion for her lover. As to alimony, Maltre Coluoci declared that counsel for the defence had erroneously stated that, even if the wife waa alone guilty, it should be granted. LB. 15 was demanded, but any alimony was out of the question, unless it could be shown that the wife was entirely innocent; in the present, where the wife alone was to blame, obligatory | alimony will quit. Maltre Coiaooi, his client was a man of feelings, and would not allow his to starve. If however, the Court granted fixed sum, such as LE 16, the wife would Mare Egypt, and go to live with the judge at h« husband’s expense. He was prepared to give her an allowance of LE 6 monthly. In spite of the protestations of Maltre Guidotti, Maltre Colucci declared that the entire family of the wife, prior to her marriage, existed on LE 8 per month, so that LE 6 for her alone was enough. This ended the speech of Maltre Colnooi.and Maltre Guidotti then ruse to rejoin but was informed by the judge that, as it was late, he should send his pleading to him and that judgment would be given in a few days’ time.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive will leave Montazah tomorrow for Cairo, and will return to Alexandria on Friday next to attend the El Orwa el-Woaka Society’s benefit performance at the Zizinia Theatre. All those who have recently been promoted it decorated will be accorded an audience with H.H. the Khedive on Monday, the 13th instant, at Abdeen Palace, at the following hours and in the order indicated: 3.30 p.m. Governors and Moudirs. 3.45 p.m. Native Tribunal and Native Bar. 4 p.m. Ministry of the Interior. Administration of the Sanitary Service, General Inspectorate of Prisons, Sanitary, Maritime and Quarantine Board, Slave Trade Reppression Department, Gouvernorate and Moudiriehs, Municipal Commissions, Ministry of Finance, Customs Administration, Administration of Porta and Lighthouses, Postal Administration, Coast Guard Administration, Public Debt Department, Daira Sanieh, Administration of Railways, Telegraphs and of the Port of Alexandria, Ministry of Public Works, Ministry of Public Instruction, Ministry of War, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Waifs Administration. 4.15 p.m. The officials who are entitled to a pension; the native and European notables; the omdehs and the sheikhs. Military visitors at this reception will appear in undress uniform and civilians in morning dress.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught have arrived at Khartoum. They are due back in Cairo on the 17th inst.

div.head: LORD CROMER’S TRIP.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.) Medinet-el-Fayoum, Saturday, 1 p.m. Lord and Lady Cromer and Lady Thynne arrived here to-day and were received by the Mondnieh officials, judges, Bedouin chiefs, village headmen, and a great gathering of other local notables. Lord Cromer made a speech touching on the cotton worm, locusts, irrigation, alcoholism, and many other matters, which was greatly appreciated. Our distinguished visitors leave for the South at 5.40 o’clock.

div.head: JUDICIAL COMMISSION.
div.p: This morning, the Lit meeting of the International Judicial Commission was held at the Mixed Court, Alexandria, under the presidency of Boutroe Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affaire. The Judicial Adviser and the Khedivial Counsellors, Messrs. Bernard and Rocca Serra, were present. The work of the Commission is now practically over. This morning’s conference was only concerned with some comparatively unimportant details.

div.head: HELLENIC CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The new judge appointed by the Greek Government as president of the Hellenic Consular Court at Alexandria, in succession to Judge Dimaras, is Mr. Xenophon Stellakia, at present president of the Hellenic Consular Court at Smyrna. The Greek Government has taken this step in consequence of the scandals associated with Judge Dim area. The matrimonial case in which he is mixed up is reported in another column of today’s issue.

div.head: THE S.S “FORTUNA."
div.p: Our Suez Correspondent informs us that there is no truth in the rumour that the S.S. "Fortuna" has been wrecked in the Bed Sea. He adds that he saw the vessel anchored yesterday morning in the Suez roads loading cargo for tour.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Indian Prince” left Manchester on Thursday with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head: NILE TOURISTS
div.p: The following passengers left Cairo on Friday by the P.S."Nefortari" for the Nile trip: Mrs. M. A. Crosley, Mrs. John R Bell, Mis. E M. and Miss E Bishop, Mr. and Mrs. N. P. Wheeler, Miss Rachel Wheeler, Miss M. Culbertson, Mrs. H. L Perry, Miss C. Franciscos, Mr. Gardner, Mr. Gardner Jur.X Mr. W. Wandelt, Prod Koroer, Miss Nitache. Miss Sehroeder, Mrs. Amstricher Jseger, Miss Stracker, M. Landrat von der Beck, Mrs. Bohm, Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Chiity, Dr. A. H. and Mrs. Ebrman, Major General Nusoh, Mr. Ramm, Mr. Gomel, Mr. Bohm, Mr. Schilling, Mr. IttoBobu.

div.head: MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon’s pleasant fixture, the Mena House Gymkhana, was attended by a large and fashionable gathering. A number of visitors came out early to Mena to lunch at the hotel before the races began at 3 o'clock, and the hospitality of Men's House was taxed to its utmost to provide lunch for the members who flocked out in the morning. The following is a list of prize-winners:— „ Donkey Ram for Gentlemen. — 1. Mr. Wright Anderson, 2. Mr. Paton, 3. Capt Curey.
Flat Race for Ponies. — 1. Ibrahim Bey Cherif 2. Mr. Fox, 3. Dr. Nolan.
General Post Stakes on Horses.—1. Mrs. Wood, 2. Mrs. Nolan.
Camel Race for Gentlemen —1. Mr. littlewood, 9. Ahmed Pareg Bey. 3. Mr. Vernon.
Ladies’ Pony Race. — 1. Mrs. Wood, 2. Mrs. Nolan.
Hubdu Race. — 1. Ibrahim Bey Cberif) 2. Ahmed Bey Cheri 3. Mr. Starkey.
Lamas Donkey Rat*.— 1. Miss Babs. HackRack—1. Mr. Colton Pox, 9. Mohamed Pouad Nomad, 3. Ahmed Pang Bey.
An extra event was for Arabs riding their own camel*. There was a field of eight Ramadam came in first, followed by Soldi and Kamel. The presentation of prizes took plaoe on the terrace of the hotel.

div.head: POINT-TO-POINT RACES.
div.p: The Abbassieh Hunt point-to-point race meeting was held yesterday at Bshet Goorgi Zigada on the left bank of the Menonfieh Canal, near the Delta Barrage. A special train left Cairo at 11.20 am. with about 75 passengers for the races, and many others came down by launch from Cairo. The enclosure, which commanded a very good view of the course, was decorated with flags, and detachments of police and ghaffirs were drawn up on the bank of the canal, at the point where the launches and barge stopped. Mr. Machell gave a large lunch party on the “Scout” and Sir William Gore tin also entertained a party on board one of the launches of the Irrigation Department. Among those present were the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Lady Londesborough, Lord and lady Dalhonsie, Major General Slade and Miss Slade, Sir William Garstin, Mr. Macbell, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, Mr. H. E Verschoyle, Mr. A. L Webb, Mr. and Mrs. Brunyate, Mr. Lockett, Mr. and Mrs. Horn-blower, Mohamed Cboukri Pasha, the Misses Harley, Mrs. Crawley, Mr. H. Rumbold, Capt the Hon. A. Stanley, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. and Mrs. Wyid, Dr. Keatings, Mr. and Mrs. Graham, Mr. Carter Wilson, Capt Gillson, Mr. and Mrs. Astley Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Mr. aud Mrs. Drummood-Hay, Capt. Biggs, B.K., Mr. Tod, Mr. Bowden-Smith, and many others. The racing good and expeditiously managed, the starts being capital.There were some tumbles bat no one came to any ham, aud the dust was the only thing that at all interfered with the pleasure of the visitors. Tbe following are the results

Landowness Race — This race resolved itself into a match between Mohamed Salam el Shedid’s horse, a grey, and a chestnut owned by Hamad el Miftah el Tabawi, who was beaten by a bare half-length. Beheri Bey Halawa won the third prixe oat of five competitors.

Hunt Cup - There were five runners in the Hunt Cup Race, of whom Capt Cummins was out of the race at the second corner owing to his hone coming down at a fence. Mr. Stanlake-Lee, though riding an Arab that had never jumped before, was in the first three till the third owner, where his mount refused a jump and cost him a couple of bandied yards Capt. Lewin was the winner, Capt the Hon. A. Stanley being a good second, and Capt Bartlett third.
Sheikhs’ Rack—Won after an amusing race by Sadi Bey Sbedid, Abdul Megib Toulba being second, and Beheri Bey Hajawa third.
Own Rack—Woo fairly easily by Capt the Hon. A. Stanley, Capt Bartlett bring second, and Mr. Lockett third, Mr. Tod dose behind.

Fellaheen Rack—There were eight entries for this race, but the bank and drain near the enclosure put several of the riders temporarily out of action, while others, after getting their hones over, were carried into bersim fields by their steeds. Eventually Mob. Abd-el-Rahman won easily. Ali Mob. Amr was second. Eizk Mati, in spite of a cropper at the obstacle above-mentioned, came in third, the remaining riders failing to finish the course.

div.head: Cairo v. Alexandria.
div.p: A cricket match, "Cairo” v. "Alexandria,’' will be played in Cairo on Friday, 17th inst, at 10.30 am. The teams are as follows

div.head: HOCKEY.
div.p: RT.C. v. Alderson's Garden. The hockey match on skates, which took place in Alderson's Garden yesterday after noon, proved a very interesting fixture arc drew a lam crowd of spectators. Play was very exciting. In the first half it proved very quick and looked in favor of the RT.C, hot during the second half Alderson’s Garden played up , well and won by 6 to A The following wen , the teams:— RT.C.—Townsend, Barnes. and Collier. Alderson’s Garden. - Douglas Alien, W Tookejr, end H. C. Tookey.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Nile season this year has never been surpassed, and Cook’s and the Anglo-American Line’s steamers are taking enormous numbers of tourists up the river. The dahabiehs and privately chartered steamers are also being well patronised. Among the distinguished departure from Cairo yesterday for the river trip was Prince Gusts via Adolphus of Sweden and Norway, who left by the S.S. "Cleopatra for Upper Egypt. The Empress Eugenie also left yesterday for a river trip with her party, on board Cook’s S.S. "Nephtis." The Empress will probably go as far at Khartoum. She was most pleased with her stay it the Savoy Hotel where she will be beck in March. The Marquis di Rudini was the guest of the evening last night at a banquet given at Cairo by Prince Husaain Pasha Kamel. On Thursday evening' the ex-Prime Minister of Italy was entertained to a banquet given by the Marquis and Marchioness Salvago-Raggi at the Italian Diplomatic Agency at Cairo. Among the guests were Prince Fuad Pasha, M.and Mme., de Martino Pasha, Marquis di Soragna, Count Arrivmbene, etc. The Marquis leaves Egypt on Wednesday next for Massowah. He will meet Sig. Martini Governor of Brythrea, at Snex. Mr. and Mrs. Rochfort Maguire are accompanying the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire on their dahabieh trip up the river. Sir Ernest Ceasel and party, including Sir Edward and lady Colebrooke are to be in Cairo for some time. They are staying at the Savoy Hotel Lady Sarah Wilson has gone up the Nile with Lord and Lady Howe. Sir Benjamin Baker, Mr. Aird, and Mr. Blue are arriving at Cairo next week.

The "At Home” given at the Carole International Mansoomh, Tuesday last, was in every way a great success. Dancing commenced about 10 o'clock and went merrily on anti! 3. There were about people present. Supper was served at 12 o’clock and amongst the 24 guests of the Moadir we noticed the British Consul and Mrs. Murdoch, Mr, Mrs, and Miss Smith, the Rev. T. Perininger, Mr, Mrs, and Miss Warner, Mr. Moberiy, Dr. Biring, Mr. Hopkins, Mr. and Mr*. Kindynekos. The president of the dub. Makaod Bey, and the vice-president, Mr. Midnatopdo, also entertained other guests. The health of the Moadir, Mustaph* Maher Pasha, was drank with social honors, and after several speeches dancing recommenced. Amongst other guests we noticed Mme. Commonoe, Mme Gertsen, Mr. George and Miss Dood, Judge Bemsn, judge Hegaus, the Russian Consul Mr. Hmkih Grets, etc. A great amounted of the success of the evening was due to the untiring efforts of Maksud Bey. The evening closed with “Should all acquaintance be forgot," “God Save the King” and the Turkish national anthem.

The United States Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General Mr. Biddle; is giving a large dinner party at the Savoy Hotel on 23rd fast. Count Kocxiebrodxki, the new Austro-Hungarian Consul-General, received the members of the office at the Savoy Hotel today.

Abdel Hamid Abaza entertained a party at diner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, the guests including Prof. Mrs. Vail Ms. and Mrs. W. C. Mackenzie. Mr. arid Mrs. Poaden, Mr. and Mrs. 8utro. Misses Houghton, Mr. H. Lonaford, and Ismail Paaha A bare. At another table Mr. Hobhouse, M. P.Creok shank Pasha, and the Maxtor of Elibank, to be seen. Baron von Kooning. Chamberlain to the Tzar, had a select party of 7. Mr. and Mm. James Speyer, Mr. ami Mrs Huntington, of New York, Mr. and Mrs. Ellerman, Mr. Joseph Walton, M.P, Dr. and Mme. Attach larger have left the Savoy Hotel for Europe. Mr. Antoine Saohtouris, Hellenic Vice Consul at Alexandria, has been promoted to the rank of consul and transferred to Uskub, Macedonia.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS DEPARTURES.
div.p: Le paquebot "Congo” des Messegeries Mari-times parti pour Marseille le 3 farrier avait a bord: M. Cotillon, M. Cornekmp, M. Coobard, M. Bandry, M. Auerbach. M. Antoine Misk, Mme Grandjren, Mme A. Worms, Mme A. Bertonx. M. Balks, et 19 pastogen de 3me et 4me classe.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class snd most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Fading the Central position. Under English management.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL LUXOR
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.
